Column Comment.0: RULE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a rule. Rules may be policies, practices,procedures or system business rules.
Column Comment.1: DETAIL SEQUENCE NUMBER: An ordered number used to sequence informationabout the rule detail in the order that they should be executed. Some business rulesmay need to be described as an ordered sequence and then constructed into acomplete command prior to execution.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: AVERAGE VALUE: The average or single value assigned to this specification. If onlyone mesuare is provided, it should be stored here.
Column Comment.6: PPDM BOOLEAN RULE: A boolean rule are part of a logical sytstem of rules, basedon mathematical rules. These represent relationships between sets of values usinglogical operators such as AND, OR, NOT, GREATER THAN, LESS THAN etc.Named after the British mathemetician George Boole.
Column Comment.7: VALUE RULE: Use this column to store the actual rule, including table and columnnames where relevant, that expresses the rule. For example, you may useWELL.SPUD_DATE>=WELL_LICENSE.LICENSE_DATE.
Column Comment.8: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format colums, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.9: EFFECTIVE DATE: date on which the data in this row came into effect.
Column Comment.10: EXPIRY DATE: Date on which the data in this row of data was no longer in effect.
Column Comment.11: MAXIMUM DATE: the maximum date, such as an expiry date, that describes thisproduct.
Column Comment.12: MAXIMUM VALUE: the maximum value for a specification, such as the maximumdiameter of a tank, or the maximum load capacity of a vehicle.
Column Comment.15: MINUMUM DATE: the minimum date associated with a specification, such as a datethat a product cannot be used for, such as for aging processes.
Column Comment.16: MINIMUM VALUE: the minimum value associated with a specification, such asminimum pipe thickness or minimum pressure capability.
Column Comment.19: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.20: COLUMN NAME: Name of the column within a specific table found in the schema. Inthis case, a reference to the system, table and column to which the business rulerefers.
Column Comment.21: REFERENCE COLUMN NAME 2: The second column name is used to supportboolean BETWEEN statements. In this case, the second name is the second columnin the pair.
Column Comment.22: SYSTEM IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a data storage system, such as adatabase or XML schema. In this case, a reference to the system, table and columnto which the business rule refers.
Column Comment.23: TABLE NAME: Name of the table found in the schema. In this case, a reference tothe system, table and column to which the business rule refers.
Column Comment.24: REFERENCE TABLE NAME 2: Where this column is used, the second table name isthe table that contains the second value in a BETWEEN boolean statement. While inmost cases, both the first and the last column used to compare the values willbe inthe same table, there are cases where it may not be.
Column Comment.25: REFERENCE VALUE: A reference value for this business rule. For some businessrules, this may be a percentage, such as a business rule that says that a value maynot vary more than 25% from some other value (this type of rule can help detecterrors in decimal placement for some types of data, such as positions or elevations).
Column Comment.27: REFERENCE VALUE TYPE: A list of the kinds of reference values that are used fordeclaration of business rules about data in your database. For example, you maystate that the reference value type is the value of another column (such as in thecase where the spud date must be after the well license date), or the case where ifone column is populated, another must also be populated (if a production volume isentered, you must also enter a unit of measure).
Column Comment.29: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.30: SPECIFICATION DESCRIPTION: A textual description of the specification property.
Column Comment.31: RULE DETAIL TYPE: the type of detail for a rule that is being captured, such as theminimum value that the column can store.
Column Comment.32: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.33: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.34: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.35: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.36: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.37: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.38: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.39: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
